transcripts.text: But first, Douglas Murray in today's Spectator magazine has said of Donald Trump's Mount Rushmore speech that was widely dismissed by the mainstream media as racist, that it is a better, far more unifying answer than the dismantling options being offered by his opponents. In our schools, our newsrooms, even our corporate boardrooms, there is a new far-left fascism that demands absolute allegiance.  If you do not speak its language, perform its rituals, recite its mantras, and follow its commandments, then you will be censored, banished, blacklisted, persecuted, and punished.

Douglas Murray is the associate editor of The Spectator and author of the book The Madness of Crowds.  He joins me now.  Douglas, fascinating column this week.  I guess your point is that actually there were some subtleties in this speech that have been missed by the mainstream media.  that actually could be one of President Trump's best hopes of re-election.

Well, first of all, good to be with you again.  I don't think there's subtleties that have been missed.  I mean, doubtless, the subtleties have been missed as well.  But the simple text of the speech has been missed.  What President Trump did at Mount Rushmore was to give the nation a history lesson, a much needed history lesson about the fact that the men carved into the mountain behind him were not, as a CNN presenter had said earlier that day, just slavers.  that the reputation, the life, the legacy of George Washington, of Thomas Jefferson, and of Abraham Lincoln, just for starters, is not some horrible history, which has to be attacked and derided, but rather a subject of great pride for the American people, the American Republic. The president gives an incredibly important speech on the eve of one of the most important days, the most important day, the founding day in the American calendar.  And it's just completely ignored.
And you say this media coverage, Douglas, is part of an unweaving of a nation.  What do you mean by that?

Well, this is a very, very interesting story that's been happening for a long time, but it's reached a fever pitch clearly in the Trump presidency.  It seems to have been the case that rather than just sort of, you know, opposing the sort of woke and revisionist history types, Trump has in some ways actually managed to make these people yell louder and in larger numbers.  But what I'm describing is a very interesting thing that's happened throughout our lifetimes, which is a basic unweaving of the fabric of the root of American society. So my suggestion is.  If the founding fathers are just slavers, it would be better if Columbus had never found America and slavery is the only story of America and white supremacy and the Constitution should be what exactly is left.  And that's the question that Donald Trump, whatever you think of him, and God knows there are criticisms to make, whatever you think of him, what he did Mount Rushmore on Friday was to say, we have a story. I mean, the list of people, great Americans who the president reeled off, including Martin Luther King, including, you know, the great moral figures, great writers, great sportsmen. Well, I don't know about that.  I think that... The relatively modern desire to think ill of your country, to think badly of your forebears and to judge yourself in a worse light than anyone else is a really very strange, very modern perversion.  It's historically very unusual.  It's a modern perversion taught from the academy outwards, which says to be sort of smart. That's a that's a pretty unusual thing.  And by the way, even in the modern age, it's characterized only in the modern West and primarily in English speaking countries.  It's a modern Australian, American, Canadian, British problem primarily.  And I think this is a sort of.  this is a period we're going through.  It'll it'll finish or at least come to less of a less prominence because it's such an unnatural position to hold.  I think that most Americans think that America is a pretty good place.  Of course, it has its faults.  But as Jean Kirkpatrick famously said in the Vietnam era, nobody doubted that America could improve.  But to improve, it had to survive.  And it's the same with Britain.  I mean, we do have people now who think that, you know, the absolutely smart thing to be is to sort of pretend you're an expert on the colonial period, say that we only did bad things and look smart at parties.  Actually, these people who are currently telling everyone else to read more tend, in my experience, to know less than almost anybody.  Most of the British public, like the American public, have a very important instinct, which is All people in history, all people, including our own history, have made mistakes and we can judge them.  But by and large, if you look at the ledger historically, we've been a force for good more than we have a force for ill.  And the American people know that.  they know that the era of the American hegemony.  has been better than it would have been if it had been an era of Chinese hegemony or North Korean hegemony or any other.  And it's the same with the British.  You know, we know that we've had a complex history like everyone else.  But we also know that, broadly speaking, we've been a force for good in the world or at least more of a force for good than for ill.  That's a perfectly reasonable insight.  It's totally justifiable.  There's no reason to feel ashamed of it.  And I think that the people who think that the sort of smarty pants thing to do is to be a sort of self lover should just realize that they are a sort of weird, weird masochist in an international marketplace of very willing and eager sadists.

Well, that's why I think there was such anger this week, actually, towards Harry and Meghan speaking out from their Los Angeles mansion to criticise the Commonwealth.  Now, Harry, you would presume, knows a little bit about it.  Meghan, I would imagine, knows not that much at all.  And they thought it was the trendy thing to do. And while is far from perfect, in many ways was set up to make up for some of those wrongs of the British Empire.

Absolutely.  And, you know, I think there's something, a lot of very weird things going on in our time.  It is slightly typified.  By having a prince and princess lecturing us on privilege. Well, I mean, it's hard to know what to laugh at more.  A bunch of people signing a letter saying, please don't cancel people and then being cancelled. Douglas Murray, associate editor of The Spectator and author of The Madness of Crowds.  Absolute pleasure to have you.
